infodynamics.utils
Class MatrixUtils

java.lang.Object
  infodynamics.utils.MatrixUtils

public class MatrixUtils
extends java.lang.Object

Utilities for computations on matrices, represented as two-dimensional arrays of doubles (double[][] matrix) - it is assumed that all multidimensional matrices have consistent lengths in each dimension matrix[i].

Author:
Joseph Lizier, joseph.lizier at gmail.com

static double[][] CholeskyDecomposition(double[][] A)
          Make the Cholesky decomposition L of a given input matrix A, where: A is symmetric and positive definite (has full rank) A = L L^T (L^T is the transpose of L - here A has real entries only, though a Cholesky decomposition is possible with complex entries) L is a lower triangular matrix We perform the decomposition using the Choleskyâ€“Banachiewicz algorithm, computing L from the top left, row by row (see wikipedia)

reorderDataForVariables

public static double[][] reorderDataForVariables(double[][] inputValues,
                                                 int[][] reordering)
Return data[x][y]: - y==0: inputValues[x][0] - y>0: inputValues[reordering[y-1][x]][y]

Parameters:
inputValues - holds the raw data values
reordering - outlines how to rearrange the raw data values for each variable or column. First index is variable or column number. Reorderings may be supplied for all of the columns of the inputValues, or for one less than all of the columns, in which case the first column is not reordered. Second index is for the row number or time step. The value at that point states which row number to pull the data from.
Returns:

                                          double[] means)

covarianceMatrix

public static double[][] covarianceMatrix(double[][] data1,
                                          double[][] data2)
Compute the covariance matrix between all column pairs (variables) in the multivariate data set, which consists of two separate multivariate vectors.

Parameters:
data1 - multivariate array of data; first index is time, second is variable number
data2 - a second multivariate array of data, which can be though of as extensions of rows of the first.
Returns:
covariance matrix, where the columns of dat1 are numbered first, and the columns of data2 after that.

covarianceMatrix

public static double[][] covarianceMatrix(double[][] data1,
                                          double[][] data2,
                                          int delay)
Compute the covariance matrix between all column pairs (variables) in the multivariate data set, which consists of two separate multivariate vectors.

Parameters:
data1 - multivariate array of data; first index is time, second is variable number
data2 - a second multivariate array of data, which can be thought of as extensions of rows of the first.
delay - compute the lagged covariance of the given delay from data1 to data2 (assumes delay >= 0); i.e. compute correlation between data1[x] and data2[x+delay].
Returns:
covariance matrix, where the columns of data1 are numbered first, and the columns of data2 after that.

covarianceMatrix

public static double[][] covarianceMatrix(double[][] data1,
                                          double[][] data2,
                                          double[][] data3)
Compute the covariance matrix between all column pairs (variables) in the multivariate data set, which consists of three separate multivariate vectors.

Parameters:
data1 - multivariate array of data; first index is time, second is variable number
data2 - a second multivariate array of data, which can be thought of as extensions of rows of the first.
data2 - a third multivariate array of data, which can be thought of as extensions of rows of the first and second.
Returns:
covariance matrix, where the columns of data1 are numbered first, the columns of data2 after that, and finally the columns of data3.

determinant of matrix
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - if supplied a non-square matrix

CholeskyDecomposition

public static double[][] CholeskyDecomposition(double[][] A)
                                        throws java.lang.Exception

Make the Cholesky decomposition L of a given input matrix A, where:

  1. A is symmetric and positive definite (has full rank)
  2. A = L L^T (L^T is the transpose of L - here A has real entries only, though a Cholesky decomposition is possible with complex entries)
  3. L is a lower triangular matrix
We perform the decomposition using the Choleskyâ€“Banachiewicz algorithm, computing L from the top left, row by row (see wikipedia)

This method has been adapted from the JAMA project (public domain software)

Parameters:
A - input matrix
Returns:
L
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - when the matrix A is not square, is asymmetric, or not positive definite
See Also:
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cholesky_decomposition}, http://mathworld.wolfram.com/CholeskyDecomposition.html}, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Positive-definite_matrix}, http://math.nist.gov/javanumerics/jama/}

invertSymmPosDefMatrix

public static double[][] invertSymmPosDefMatrix(double[][] A)
                                         throws java.lang.Exception
Compute matrix inversion of a symmetric, positive definite matrix by using the Cholesky Decomposition L of the matrix A. Since A = L L^T, then A^-1 = (L^T)^-1 L^-1, and the inverses of

Parameters:
A - matrix to be inverted
Returns:
the inverse of A
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - when the matrix is not symmetric or positive definite
See Also:
CholeskyDecomposition(double[][])

solveViaCholeskyResult

public static double[][] solveViaCholeskyResult(double[][] L,
                                                double[][] B)

Solve A*X = B, where A = L*L^T via Cholesky decomposition.

This method has been adapted from the JAMA project (public domain software)

Parameters:
L - Cholesky decomposition of the matrix A
B - matrix with as many rows as A and any number of columns
Returns:
X so that A*X = B
See Also:
http://math.nist.gov/javanumerics/jama/}, CholeskyDecomposition(double[][])

determinantSymmPosDefMatrix

public static double determinantSymmPosDefMatrix(double[][] A)
                                          throws java.lang.Exception

Compute determinant(A), where A = L*L^T via Cholesky decomposition is a symmetric, positive definite matrix.

This is an efficient computation, since det(A) = det(L*L^T) = det(L)*det(L^T) and L is triangular so det(L) is just the product along the diagonal

Parameters:
A - symmetric, positive definite matrix to take the determinant of
Returns:
the determinant of A
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - when the matrix is not symmetric or positive definite

determinantViaCholeskyResult

public static double determinantViaCholeskyResult(double[][] L)

Compute determinant(A), where A = L*L^T via Cholesky decomposition is a symmetric, positive definite matrix.

This is an efficient computation, since det(A) = det(L*L^T) = det(L)*det(L^T) and L is triangular so det(L) is just the product along the diagonal

Parameters:
L - Cholesky decomposition L of the symmetric positive definite matrix A
Returns:
det(A)
See Also:
CholeskyDecomposition(double[][])

doubleTo2DArray

public static double[][] doubleTo2DArray(double[] array)
Convert a single dimensional double array to a 2D array, where the first dimension matches that of the original array and second is always 0 (with our convention for first index being time and second variable number, this means we have a 2D array where the original array becomes the first variable).

Parameters:
array -
Returns:
2D array with the original array as the only column.

doubleToIntArray

public static int[] doubleToIntArray(double[] array)
Convert a double array to an int array. This is designed specifically for use of the toolkit in Octave where all native arrays are considered as doubles for Java. To use an integer 1D array (to supply to a java method), one must first create the native Octave 1D array, then create a java 1D Double array, then use this method to convert that java 1D Double array to a java 1D integer array.

Parameters:
array -
Returns:

doubleToIntArray

public static int[][] doubleToIntArray(double[][] array)
Convert a 2D double array to an int array. This is designed specifically for use of the toolkit in Octave where all native arrays are considered as doubles for Java. To use an integer 2D array (to supply to a java method), one must first create the native Octave 2D array, then create a java 2D Double array, then use this method to convert that java 2D Double array to a java 2D integer array.

Parameters:
array -
Returns:
